sen.j: 受領名(ずりょうめい)は非公式な官名のこと。
sen.e: Zuryomei was an unofficial name for government posts.
Zuryomei were unofficial names for government posts.
sen.cmt: was an unofficial name --> were unofficial names
sen.e: Zuryomei were unofficial names for government posts.

sen.j: 朝廷や寺院が出入りの商工業者に名乗ることを許した非公式な官名。
sen.e: This was the unofficial name for government posts which the Imperial Court and temples allowed merchants and traders going in and out to use.
They were unofficial names for government posts which the Imperial Court and temples allowed merchants and traders, coming in and going out of the Court and temples, to use.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: They were unofficial names for government posts which the Imperial Court and temples allowed merchants and traders, coming in and going out of the Court and temples, to use.

sen.j: 主に室町時代から戦国時代 (日本)にかけて守護大名、戦国大名が武功や功績ある家臣に対して授けた非公式な官名。
sen.e: Mainly over the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (period of warring states), this was also an unofficial name of government post granted to vassals who had made military exploits and achievements by shugo daimyo (shugo were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords) and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period.

Mainly over the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (period of warring states), they were granted as an unofficial name of government post to vassals who had made military exploits and achievements by shugo daimyo (shugo were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords) and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period.
sen.cmt: this was also an unofficial name of government post granted to vassals --> they were granted as an unofficial name of government post to vassals
sen.e: Mainly over the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (period of warring states), they were granted as an unofficial name of government post to vassals who had made military exploits and achievements by shugo daimyo (shugo were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords) and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 朝廷・寺院の授ける受領名
sen.e: Zuryomei which were given by the Imperial Court and temples
Zuryomei given by the Imperial Court and temples
Zuryomei given by the Imperial Court and temples

sen.j: 京都においては、朝廷や御所や寺院の用をはたす商工業者や芸能者に限り、家格や家業に箔をつけさせるため、金品次第により守、介、掾などの受領名を授け、特権的立場を与えた。
sen.e: In Kyoto, only merchants, traders and performers, who had businesses with the Imperial Court, Gosho (Imperial Palace) and temples, were granted the Zuryomei such as Kami (Governor), Suke (Vice Governor) and Jo (Provincial Governor), and a privileged position to increase their prestige for the social standing and family business.

In Kyoto, only merchants, traders and performers, who had businesses with the Imperial Court, Gosho (Imperial Palace) and temples, were granted the Zuryomei such as Kami (Governor), Suke (Vice Governor) and Jo (Provincial Governor), and a privileged position to increase their prestige for the social standing and family business.

In Kyoto, only merchants, traders and performers, who had businesses with the Imperial Court, Gosho (Imperial Palace) and temples, were granted the Zuryomei such as Kami (Governor), Suke (Vice Governor) and Jo (Provincial Governor), and a privileged position to increase their prestige for the social standing and family business.

sen.j: 受領名を有する商工業者が扱う商品は、ブランドとしての付加価値が認められ、同じ業種の職人がつくった商品の中でも、破格の値段で取引される。
sen.e: Merchandise dealt by merchants and traders with the Zuryomei was more valuable as a brand and traded for the most extraordinary price in merchandise made by craftsmen from the same industry.
Merchandise dealt by merchants and traders with the Zuryomei was more valuable as a brand and traded at the most extraordinary price among the merchandise made by craftsmen in the same industry.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: Merchandise dealt by merchants and traders with the Zuryomei was more valuable as a brand and traded at the most extraordinary price among the merchandise made by craftsmen in the same industry.

sen.j: こうしたことから、多くの業者が自身の名誉と商売繁盛を期して受領名を求めた。
sen.e: Therefore, many merchants and traders sought the Zuryomei for their honor and prosperous trade.
Therefore, many merchants and traders sought the Zuryomei for their honor and prosperous trade.
Therefore, many merchants and traders sought the Zuryomei for their honor and prosperous trade.

sen.j: 特に戦乱に疲弊し、武家に荘園を横領されてきた朝廷や寺院にとり、官位や受領名の授与は、貴重な収入源でもあった。
sen.e: Especially for the Imperial Court and temples which were exhausted by a maelstrom of wars and grabbed Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) by samurai family, to grant official rank and the Zuryomei was a valuable source of income.

Especially for the Imperial Court and temples which were exhausted by maelstroms of war and grabs for Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) made by samurai families, to grant official rank and the Zuryomei was an essential source of income.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: Especially for the Imperial Court and temples which were exhausted by maelstroms of war and grabs for Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) made by samurai families, to grant official rank and the Zuryomei was an essential source of income.
Zuryomei in samurai families
Zuryomei in samurai families
Zuryomei in samurai families

sen.j: 室町時代以降、守護大名の間において武功ある家臣や被官に対して、朝廷の正式な位階や除目の伴わない、非公式な官名を授ける風習が生まれる。
sen.e: After the Muromachi period, the custom of being granted unofficial name of government post without official Ikai (Court rank) and Jimoku (appointment ceremonies) by the Imperial Court for vassals and hikan (low-level bureaucrats) who had made military exploits started among shugo daimyo.

After the Muromachi period, shugo daimyo started the custom of granting unofficial names of government post without official Ikai (Court rank) and Jimoku (appointment ceremonies) from the Imperial Court, to vassals and hikan (low-level bureaucrats) who had made military exploits.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: After the Muromachi period, shugo daimyo started the custom of granting unofficial names of government post without official Ikai (Court rank) and Jimoku (appointment ceremonies) from the Imperial Court, to vassals and hikan (low-level bureaucrats) who had made military exploits.
This was the Zuryomei.
These unofficial names were the Zuryomei.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: These unofficial names were the Zuryomei.

sen.j: 多くの場合、大名の傘下にあって城や領地、兵力を有する国人や武将がその対象であった。
sen.e: In many cases, the Zuryomei was given to Kokujin (local samurai) and Busho (Japanese military commanders) who were under the control of daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) and also had a castle, territory and military strength.

In many cases, the Zuryomei was given to Kokujin (local samurai) and Busho (Japanese military commanders) who were under the control of daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) and also had a castle, territory and military strength.

In many cases, the Zuryomei was given to Kokujin (local samurai) and Busho (Japanese military commanders) who were under the control of daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) and also had a castle, territory and military strength.

sen.j: この風習が転化し、自官や百官名、東百官という人名呼称が武士の間において定着するようになる。
sen.e: The custom later changed and the naming such as jikan (official name which samurai called himself without the Imperial Court's involvement), hyakkan na (a name taken after his/her or family's official rank) and azuma hyakkan (titles conferred on daimyo and samurai) became popular among samurai.
sen.cmt: 自官・・・読み不明、定訳不明
sen.e: The custom later changed into a state in which the naming such as jikan (official name which samurai called himself without the Imperial Court's involvement), hyakkan na (a name taken after his/her or family's official rank) and azuma hyakkan (titles conferred on daimyo and samurai) became popular among samurai.
sen.cmt: The custom later changed and --> The custom later changed into a state in which
sen.e: The custom later changed into a state in which the naming such as jikan (official name which samurai called himself without the Imperial Court's involvement), hyakkan na (a name taken after his/her or family's official rank) and azuma hyakkan (titles conferred on daimyo and samurai) became popular among samurai.

sen.j: こうした主君から受領名を授かる際に交付されるのが官途書出、あるいは受領書出、官途状などといい、武家の格式と功名をあらわす栄誉として重んじられた。
sen.e: When the Zuryomei was given by a lord, written appointment of a government service called such as kanto no kakidashi, zuryo no kakidashi and kantojo was issued and it was respected as an honor representing a social status and fame of samurai family.

When the Zuryomei was given by a lord, written appointment to a government service called kanto no kakidashi, zuryo no kakidashi, kantojo or the like was issued, which was respected as an honor representing a social status and fame of samurai family.
sen.cmt: appointment ofのofを toに変更、その他表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: When the Zuryomei was given by a lord, written appointment to a government service called kanto no kakidashi, zuryo no kakidashi, kantojo or the like was issued, which was respected as an honor representing a social status and fame of samurai family.
